div.p:

But if, immediately vpon one of the≈øe chill and tedious nights, there ≈øhould ≈øhine foorth an vnexpected Summer≈øday, which were neuer to be intercepted by any night, or winter, or irke≈øomne≈ø≈øe at all, how would we be taken with delight, and admiration. The ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle Saint
Paul, after a very long & many wayes dark≈øome night, ob≈øeruing, that now there had approached both to him≈øelfe, and to his deare brethren in Chri≈øt, a day in many re≈øpects mo≈øt happie, which was to expect no night at all, with this congratulatory ≈øpeech addre≈ø≈øeth him≈øelfe to them, and giueth this watchword, ≈øaying, Nox praece≈øsit; dies autem appropinquauit. The night is pa≈øt, and the day is at hand.

With the ≈øame ≈øentence may I fitly now furni≈øh my ≈øelfe, in this my fir≈øt ≈øpeech, for an affectionate congratulation with you, my beloued brethren of Italie, and you my other auditors heere a≈ø≈øembled to heare me. Fora≈ømuch as I haue at this time ≈øet my ≈øelfe no other taske, then to pre≈øent in common mine owne ioyes, together with yours: my comming into the≈øe parts being, not to teach others, but to be taught my ≈øelfe, not to be an in≈øtructor, but to be in≈øtructed, and ≈øet aright. Now therefore hauing vndertaken, for ≈øatisfying the de≈øire, and pious reque≈øt of many, to ≈øpeake vnto you this day, and happily againe hereafter in the like
maner, I intend to hold my ≈øelfe to my wonted ≈øimplicity of preaching, and plainne≈ø≈øe of ≈øtile, and to keepe aloofe from all choice phra≈øes, and affected ≈øtreines of Italian elegancies, contenting my ≈øelfe rather to worke vpon the affections, then to ≈øatisfie the vnder≈øtanding.

I re≈øume therefore my Text, and ≈øay, Nox praece≈øsit &c. The night is pa≈øt, the day commeth on. Let vs ca≈øt off the workes of darknes, and put on the armour of light. The≈øe foure briefe propo≈øitions ≈øhall be the foure points of this pre≈øent Exerci≈øe.

div.p:
BVt before we vndertake the handling of the≈øe particulars, we are to pre≈øent our ≈øelues in hearty praiers before the throne of the diuine Maie≈øtie, humblie reque≈øting our heauenly Father, fir≈øt to ca≈øt the tender eyes of
his mercy vpon his vniuer≈øall holy Church, and that it would plea≈øe him by his ≈øpirit to vnite all Chri≈øtian Churches in the onely, true, pure, and holy faith, to combine them in perfect charity, to extingui≈øh all di≈øunions, to make vp all rents and ≈øchi≈ømes, to mollifie all hardned hearts, that they may ca≈øt off their ob≈øtinacie, and lay a≈øide all humane re≈øpects, and de≈øeignes; that ≈øo all ob≈øtacles, hindering this ≈øo important vnion, may be remooued. Let vs pray for all Chri≈øtian Princes, that God would kindle in their hearts a feruent zeale to procure the generall reformation of the Church, and to ≈øet forward this holy vnion. In ≈øpeciall let vs pray for his mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie of Great Britaine, the true Defender of the true ancient, pure, & holy, Catholique, and Apo≈øtolique faith: that God would in his owne hands hold his Maie≈øties heart, and continue ≈øtill turning, and plying it to his holy ≈øeruice, and to the accompli≈øhing of what≈øoeuer tendeth to the ≈øpirituall, and temporall good of this mo≈øt flouri≈øhing kingdome: that he would giue him a long

He ble≈ø≈øe with all pro≈øperity the Queenes Maie≈øtie: Hee with his grace a≈ø≈øi≈øt the mo≈øt noble Prince Charles, e≈øpecially in the≈øe his tender yeeres, which v≈øually hold fa≈øt the fir≈øt good impre≈ø≈øions; Infu≈øe, O Lord, into him feare of thy holy name, zeale of pietie, and religion, and the imitation of the ≈øolide and true Regall vertues of his Father. Let vs pray for all Prelates, Prie≈øts, and Mini≈øters of the holy Vniuer≈øall Church: In ≈øpeciall for tho≈øe that mannage the ≈øpirituall affaires in the≈øe kingdomes, that they may performe their ≈øeruice to God, and to his holy Church with true zeale, and an vpright heart. Let vs pray for all the Nobility of the≈øe kingdomes, that God would keepe and maintaine them in their due fealtie toward God, and toward their King, and alwayes incline their hearts to good, and holy de≈øeignes. Pray we for all the people, that God would ble≈ø≈øe them with all aboundance of ≈øpirituall, and temporall ble≈ø≈øings. La≈øtly let vs pray, that God would grant me ≈øuch grace, that, in publi≈øhing his ≈øacred word, I may both my ≈øelfe reape inwardly true ≈øpirituall fruit, and reach foorth the like to this honourable audience. THE no le≈ø≈øe enlightned, then beloued Di≈øciple of our Sauiour, Saint Iohn the Apo≈øtle, Euangeli≈øt, & Prophet, intending to compri≈øe in a very ≈ømall abridgement, the whole doctrine of the Go≈øpel, and to ≈øhew what was the aime, and ≈øcope, whereto all Euangelicall preaching mu≈øt tend, in≈øi≈øted vpon two briefe propo≈øitions combined together, but by relation of contrariety; the one affirmatiue, the other negatiue, both concerning God. And before he ≈øets them forth, in his fir≈øt Epi≈øtle he premi≈øeth a faire troope to make way for them. Quod fuit ab initio &c. Iohn 1.1. That which was from the beginning, which wee haue heard, which we haue ≈øeene with our eyes, which we haue looked vpon, and our hands haue handled of the word of life. For the life was manife≈øted, and wee haue ≈øeene it, and beare witnes, and ≈øhew vnto you that eternall life, which was with the Father, and was manife≈øted vnto vs. And yet, not content with this great preparation, hee repeateth againe, and ≈øaith, That, which wee haue ≈øeene, and heard, declare we vnto you, that yee al≈øo may haue fellow≈øhippe with vs; and our fellow≈øhippe
is with the Father, and with his ≈øonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Now therefore hauing awakened vs with touching vpon the exceeding benefit of being receiued into fellow≈øhippe with the holy Apo≈øtles, by receiuing that, which hee thus propoundeth to vs; let him ≈øay at the la≈øt, what this is of ≈øo great importance, which was from the beginning, that is, from beyond all eternity: which the holy Apo≈øtles had heard, and handled with their hands, which ≈øhould bring vs eternall life, and which they were to preach, and teach thorowout the world: Let him ≈øay, and declare it in a word, we will heare it. Ethaec e≈øt annunciatio &c. This is the me≈ø≈øage, which we haue heard, and declare vnto you. Well: Ble≈ø≈øed Saint Iohn, we are ready, and prepared to heare this your admirable and my≈øterious me≈ø≈øage: vnfold at length that, which you haue heard, and learnt, and receiued to report vnto vs. Behold, heere it followeth in few words: Quoniam Deus lux e≈øt; & in eo tenebrae non ≈øunt vllae; That God is light, and in him there is no darkenes at all. Behold this is the ab≈øtract, and ≈øumme of our faith, That God
is light without darkne≈ø≈øe. Therefore our eternall ≈øaluation confi≈øteth in receiuing this light, and in ca≈øting out darkne≈ø≈øe. Deus lux e≈øt &c. God is light.

If God him≈øelfe be light, what maruaile then, that hee ≈øo delighteth to imploy him≈øelfe about light. The fir≈øt inward Word, which God from all eternity brought forth within him≈øelfe, what was it but his ≈øub≈øtantiall, eternall word, his only begotten ≈øonne, whom we know to be Lumen de lumine, light of light. Likewi≈øe the fir≈øt externall word of God, which he vttered out of him≈øelfe after an eternity of ≈øilence, was this, Fiat lux, Let there be light. Light, a creature ≈øo beloued of the Creator, that he thought good to be≈øtow this one and onely quality as a ≈øufficient dowrie on the heauenly bodies, which are the mo≈øt noble and exalted creatures in all the ranke of ≈øen≈øible ≈øub≈øtances. But will ye yet further ob≈øerue, how great a friend God is to light, and enemie to darkne≈ø≈øe? Behold hee would not ≈øuffer his new

The Sunne and Moone the two great lights, together with the other le≈ø≈øer lights of the ≈øtarres, were to bee made the fourth day: and yet, becau≈øe in this meane while darknes was vpon the face of the deepe, in the fir≈øt di≈øtingui≈øhing of things out of the confu≈øed lumpe, God, as enemie of this darkne≈ø≈øe, ≈øayd, Let there be light; and there was light. Light the fir≈øt borne of all the vi≈øible creatures: light, which hath no po≈øitiue contrary in nature: light, which di≈øplayeth it ≈øelfe to all, and maketh all things el≈øe manife≈øt: light, which pierceth euery tran≈øparent body though mo≈øt ≈øolide: light, the ioy of the eyes, and comfort of euery afflicted heart. Quale gaudium e≈øt mihi, qui in tenebris ≈øedeo, & lumen coeli nen video? What ioy can I take, that ≈øit in darknes, and behold not the light of heauen? ≈øayd good old Tobia, when hee was blinde: Light, which transfu≈øeth it ≈øelfe in a moment: light, which cannot be defiled by the touch of things impure: light, which giueth life to all colours, and actuateth them: light,
the mother of all beauties, and ornaments of this ≈øen≈øible world. And generally al colours, which cloath with ≈øuch beauty the be≈øt vi≈øible bodies, and repre≈øent them to the eie with delight, what are they el≈øe, but mixtures of the light≈øome elements with the ob≈øcure. To conclude, light may by way of re≈øemblance, and participation be accompted a diuine thing, ina≈ømuch as God is light, and in him there is no darkenes. And therefore as ≈øoone, as God had created the light, the pen of the Holy Gho≈øt te≈øtifieth, that God ≈øaw the light that it was good, and diuided the light from the darkne≈øse. Vpon the atchieuement of euery other daies work, the Scripture clo≈øeth vp with this, Et vidit Deus, quod e≈ø≈øet bonum; And God ≈øaw that it was good. Yee haue often reade, and many of you con≈øidered the ≈øtrange maner of ≈øpeech v≈øed in the holy Scriptures, in the di≈øtinction of the ≈øix dayes of the Creation.
